subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Honk
entries: Druids that follow the Circle of the Honk channel their powers through the ferocity and hatred of the goose. Their order gathers under forgotten bridges or hidden marshes to share news or plan new attacks on nearby settlements. Druids of this circle delight in sowing chaos and mistrust amongst the common folk that would encroach on their sacred lands.

Unlike other druids, members of the Circle of the Honk draw their druidic power from the fury of the honk itself, transforming themselves into various goose-kin creatures to better harass their foes. Such creatures range from the humble-but-aggressive {@creature pond goose|CircleoftheHonk} to the unstoppable chaotic might of the {@creature gooseflayer|CircleoftheHonk}.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Forms
entries: The goosely spirit manifested by your circle grants you the ability to transform into a plethora of goose forms in addition to your other Wild Shapes, detailed at the end of this supplement. Starting at 2nd level, you can use your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid|PHB|2|PHB} to transform into one of these forms that has a challenge rating as high as 1, regardless of whether it is a beast or not (you ignore the max. CR column of the Beast Shapes table, though if your goose form has a flying or swimming speed, you can't use those features until you reach the noted levels on the table). If one of these forms has an action or trait that has a recharge value, you can use the action or trait once, and must then finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. The number of uses increases to 2 at 14th level, and 3 at 17th level. Additionally, starting at 6th level, you can transform into a goose form with a challenge rating as high as your druid level divided by 3, rounded down.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your mystical connection to your goose circle infuses you with the ability to cast certain spells. At 3rd, 5th, 7th and 9th level, you gain access to additional circle spells, detailed at the end of this supplement.

Once you gain access to a circle spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells can you prepare each day. Though the spells do not appear on the druid spell list, they are nonetheless a druid spells for you.

subclassFeature.name: Combat Goose Shape
entries: When you choose this circle at 2nd level, you gain the ability to use {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid|PHB|2|PHB} on your turn as a bonus action, rather than as an action.

Additionally, you gain access to additional {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid|PHB|2|PHB} options, listed at the end of this supplement. You don't need to have previously seen these new creatures to transform into them, as the power of each of them resides within your very being.

subclassFeature.name: Thieving Pecks
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you hit a creature in goose form with your beak attack, you can attempt to magically steal an object or weapon the target is carrying.

The target creature must make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (their choice) vs your druid spell save DC. On a failure, the target takes {@damage 1d6} piercing damage and you successfully steal the item. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage and you don't steal the item.
When you successfully steal an item from a target, you can use your reaction to immediately move up to half your movement without provoking {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}.

If you are carrying an item in your beak and have no other beaks free, you can't use your Thieving Peck again until you drop the item. If your goose form has multiple heads, you can choose any head to carry the item.

If the item is a melee weapon, you are considered proficient with it for as long as it remains held in your beak, and can make melee weapon attacks with it in replace of your goose form's beak attack. If the weapon is magical, you must first attune to it as normal in order to use its other properties.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1), and only once per turn. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Peace Was Never An Option
entries: When you reach 10th level, you can't be {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

In addition, while you are in goose shape you have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing and slashing damage, and when you use a goose form's Honk action, creatures have disadvantage on saving throws against it.

subclassFeature.name: Honk Of Defiance
entries: Beginning at 14th level, when you would be subjected to a magical effect, spell, or feature from a creature you can see within 60 feet of you that calls for a saving throw, you can use your reaction to magically emit a defiant honk of fowlish fury in an attempt to interrupt it. The target creature must make a Wisdom saving throw versus your druid spell save DC. On a failed save, the spell or feature fails and has no effect.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

spell.name: Distracting Honk
entries: You emit a magical honk at one creature within range. You don't need to see the creature, only be aware of its presence and know it is within range of the spell. If the target can hear you, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} thunder damage, and has disadvantage on the next ability check it makes before the end of its next turn.
This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d6}), 11th level ({@dice 3d6}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d6}).

spell.name: Elemental Goose
entries: You conjure an elemental spirit within range that takes the form of a goose and lasts for the duration or until you cast this spell again. When the elemental appears, choose one of the following damage types: acid, cold, fire, lightning or thunder. The elemental assumes a visual form representative of the chosen damage type. For example, if you choose fire, the elemental might appear as a flaming goose with eyes of coal and a body made of burning brimstone, or if you chose thunder, the elemental might appear as a crackling black cloud in the shape of a hissing goose head.

When the elemental first appears, you can have it make a melee spell attack against a creature within 5 feet of it, using your spellcasting ability modifier. On a hit, the target creature takes {@damage 2d6} damage of the chosen type.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the elemental up to 25 feet and repeat the attack against a creature within 5 feet of it.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th-level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each level above 3rd.

spell.name: Ganderstrike
entries: You call forth a bolt of burning radiance which takes the form of a goose in flight, and direct it to strike a point you can see within range. The goose flies towards that point and explodes with a thunderous honk. Each creature in a 20-foot radius sphere centered on that point must make a Strength saving throw. A target takes {@damage 6d6} thunder damage on a failed save, or takes half as much damage on a successful one. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is also pushed 20 feet away from the point in a straight line, landing {@condition prone} on a failed save, or is pushed 10 feet away and isn't knocked {@condition prone} on a success.
Small objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried are thrown 30 feet away from the point in a straight line.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Gooseberry
entries: You infuse 3 berries in your hand with fowlish magic. The berries retain this magic for 8 hours or until consumed, after which point they vanish in a puff of feathers. A creature can use its action to eat one berry. Eating a berry instills in the target a brief surge of goosely rage, granting it a +1 bonus to attack rolls for 1 minute. For the duration, the creature can speak only in honks, and can't {@status concentration||concentrate} on spells. These effects end early if the creature hasn't attacked a hostile creature since its last turn, or if it is knocked {@condition unconscious}. Additionally, if a creature eats 3 or more berries within the same 24 hour window, it is magically transformed into a {@creature pond goose|CircleoftheHonk} for 1 hour. After reverting, the creature is then immune to the berry's effects for the next 24 hours.

spell.name: Gosling Gaggle

components.m: a carton of eggs and a goose feather

entries: A honking, swarming gaggle of tiny flapping goslings fill a 20-foot radius sphere centered on a point you choose within range. The sphere spreads around corners, and movement within the sphere's area is {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. You can use your action to move the sphere up to 25 feet in a direction you choose.

When the sphere appears, each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 6d6} piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. A creature must also make this saving throw when it enters the spell's area for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the sphere's radius increases by 5 feet for each slot level above 5th.

spell.name: Hadar's Harrowing Honks
entries: You point towards one creature you can see within range and force it to make a Wisdom saving throw or become cursed for the duration of this spell.
While cursed, the target is assailed by debilitating ethereal geese that only they can see. When you cast this spell, choose one action for the geese to perform from the following options:

items: Whenever the target would be spoken to, either directly or indirectly, the geese honk wildly, briefly {@condition deafened||deafening} the target until the speech ends.
The geese interpose themselves in front of the target and beat their wings. For the duration, the target has disadvantage on attack rolls and Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

entries: The geese attach themselves to the target's head and magically cause the target to see all other creatures as geese for the duration of the curse. When a creature speaks, the target hears a series of honks or hisses, even if a creature communicates with the target telepathically.

The target sees other creatures as geese relative to their original size, such as a Tiny goose if the creature is a {@creature rat}, or a Medium goose if the creature is a human. The geese retain their counterpart's equipment in whatever comical fashion the DM deems appropriate.

items: Whenever the target attempts to sleep or enter a meditative state such as with {@race elf|PHB|elves} or {@race warforged|ERLW}, the geese honk and bite the target, shocking the target awake unless the sleep was induced by a spell of 5th-level or higher. In addition, spells of 4th-level or lower that would magically put the target to sleep have no effect.

When {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell, the geese honk aggressively and swarm the target by biting at its ankles. At the beginning of each of its turns, the target must make a Constitution saving throw versus your spell save DC to maintain {@status concentration}.

entries: A {@spell remove curse} spell ends this effect. At the DM's option, you may choose an alternative action for the geese to take, but it should be no more powerful than those described above. The DM has final say on a such a curse's effect.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels:
entries: If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the duration is {@status concentration}, up to 8 hours. If you use a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the duration is 24 hours. If you use a 9th level spell slot, the spell lasts until it is dispelled. Using a spell slot of 7th level or higher grants a duration that doesn't require {@status concentration}.

spell.name: Illusory Gander
entries: You conjure an illusory silver goose in an unoccupied point that you can see within range. The goose lasts for the duration or until you dismiss it as an action. The goose vanishes if it is ever more than 30 feet away from you, or if you cast this spell again. The goose can interact with nonmagical objects that aren't being worn or carried, but can't pass through walls, objects, terrain, or interact with creatures.

If a creature touches the goose, it fades away with a quiet honk. If a creature uses its action to examine the goose, it can determine that the goose is an illusion with a successful Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the goose to be an illusion, the goose becomes faint to the creature.

You can use your action to control the illusory goose. You can use the goose to manipulate an object, emit a shrill honk audible out to 30 feet, open an unlocked door or container, retrieve an item from a container, or spill the contents out of a container.

The goose can't carry objects that weigh more than 40 pounds, and can only carry one object at a time. If an object weighs more than 5 pounds, the goose drags it along the floor instead of carrying it.

spell.name: Investiture of Goosely Fury
entries: Tawny feathers spread across your body, creating a downy armor that protects you from harm. Until the spell ends, you gain the following benefits:

items: You are immune to thunder damage, and have a +1 bonus to AC.
You gain temporary hit points at the beginning of each of your turns equal to twice your spellcasting ability modifier.
You manifest a pair of feathery wings, which grant you a flight speed of 60 feet. If you are still flying when the spell ends, you fall, unless you can somehow prevent it.

You can use your action to create a booming honk which radiates out from you in a 15-foot sphere. Each creature of your choice in the area must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 4d6} thunder damage and is {@condition deafened} for 1 minutes on a failed save, or takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition deafened} on a successful one. A {@condition deafened} creature can attempt the saving throw again at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Goosely Foresight (1/Day)
entries: When a creature within 60 feet of the begander makes an attack roll, ability check or saving throw, the begander can spend its reaction to roll a {@dice d8} and adding or subtract the number rolled from the creature's total.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The begander has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Honk
entries: The begander emits two magical honks from its goose heads, choosing targets it can see within 60 feet of it. It can't choose the same honk twice in succession.

items.name: 1. Paralyzing Honk
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: 2. Confusing Honk
entries: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be unable to take reactions for 1 minute. In addition, the target must roll a {@dice d10} at the start of each of its turns to determine its behavior for that turn.
The creature uses all its movement to move in a random direction. To determine the direction, roll a {@dice d8} and a assign a direction to each die face.

items.name: 2–6:
entries: The creature doesn't move this turn.

items.name: 7–8:
entries: The creature uses its action to make a melee attack against a randomly determined creature within its reach. If there is no creature within its reach, the creature instead targets themselves.

items.name: 9–10:
entries: The creature can move and act normally.
The target creature can attempt the saving throw again at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: 3. Frightening Honk
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: 4. Thundering Honk
items.entry: The targeted creature must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: 5. Cursing Honk
items.entry: The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become cursed for 1 minute. While cursed, the target must make a Wisdom saving throw at the start of each of its turns. If it fails, it wastes its action that turn doing nothing. A {@spell remove curse} spell ends this effect.

items.name: 6. Conflagrating Honk
items.entry: The target briefly bursts into green flames. The target must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. It takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

items.name: 7. Goosifying Honk
items.entry: The target must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature magically begins to sprout feathers and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is transformed into a {@creature pond goose|CircleoftheHonk} {@homebrew |(see earlier in this supplement)} until freed by the {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic. Any items the creature was wearing or carrying fall to the ground in its space, and if the creature dies while transformed, it remains in that form and doesn't revert.

items.name: 8. Force Honk
items.entry: If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be hurled up to 30 feet in a direction of the begander's choice (including upwards), landing {@condition prone}. If the creature comes into contact with a hard surface or heavy object, the target creature takes {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet moved.

trait.name: Fearless Fowl
entries: The goose has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The goose can hold its breath for 10 minutes while underwater.

trait.name: Savage Attacker (1/Short Rest)
entries: When the goose rolls damage for a melee weapon attack, it can reroll the attack's damage dice and use either total.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The goose makes two beak attacks.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Honk (1/Day)
entries: The goose emits a terrifying honk in a 15-foot-radius sphere. Creatures that can hear the goose and are aware of it must make a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of the goose for 1 minute.

trait.name: Creature of Chaos
entries: The gandra's heads are constantly vying for dominance, often fighting amongst themselves when given the opportunity to do so. If the gandra begins its turn with fourteen heads or more, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight until its number of heads is reduced to thirteen or less.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The gandra can hold its breath for 1 hour.

trait.name: Multiple Heads
entries: The gandra has eight heads. While it has more than one head, the gandra has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}. Whenever the gandra takes 15 or more slashing damage in a single turn or uses its Head Toss action, one of its heads dies. If all its heads die, the gandra dies. At the end of its turn, it grows two heads for each of its heads that died since its last turn, unless it has taken fire damage since its last turn. The gandra regains 3 ({@dice 1d6}) hit points for each head regrown in this way.

trait.name: Reactive
entries: For each head the gandra has beyond one, it gets an extra reaction that can be used only to make a Ganderous Glare.

trait.name: Wakeful
entries: While the gandra sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gandra makes as many beak attacks as it has heads.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Cacophony of Honks {@recharge 5}
entries: The gandra emits a thunder burst of honks in a 30-foot cone. Creatures in the area that can hear the honks must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) thunder damage per gandra head (to a maximum of {@dice 14d6}) and is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute on a failed save, or takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition deafened} on a successful one. A {@condition deafened} creature can attempt the saving throw again at the end of its subsequent turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Head Toss ({@recharge 4|m}, requires two or more heads)
entries: The gandra rips off one of its own heads and throws it towards a creature it can see within 60 feet of it. That creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 17 ({@damage 5d6}) bludgeoning damage. If the creature is Medium or smaller, it is also knocked {@condition prone} and {@condition restrained} underneath the severed head until the target or another creature uses its action to free it.

reaction.name: Ganderous Glare
entries: When a creature within 30 feet of the gandra targets it with an attack roll, one of the gandra's heads swivels around to meet it with a menacing glare. If the target creature can see the glaring head, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on the attack roll. This has no effect on creatures that can't be {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The dragoose can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Fearless Fighter
entries: When the dragoose attacks a creature, it gains immunity to the {@condition frightened} condition until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragoose makes two beak attacks.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Fowlish Presence
entries: Each creature of the dragoose's choice that is within 60 feet of the dragoose and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragoose's Fowlish Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Honk of Fiery Fury {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragoose honks furiously, exhaling gout of fire in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 17 ({@damage 5d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The gooseflayer's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}), It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The gooseflayer has advantage on saving throws against spells or other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gooseflayer makes two mind beak attacks.

action.name: Mind Beak
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) psychic damage.

action.name: Psychic Honk {@recharge 5}
entries: The gooseflayer magically emits a psychic honk in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in the area must succeed on a {@dc 14} Intelligence saving throw or take 24 ({@damage 6d6 + 3}) psychic damage and be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Goosifying Honk (3/Day)
entries: If a creature starts its turn within 30 feet of the goosilisk and the two of them can see each other, the goosilisk can use its reaction to force the creature to make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw if the goosilisk isn't {@condition incapacitated}. On a failed save, the creature magically begins to sprout feathers and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is transformed into a {@creature pond goose|CircleoftheHonk} {@homebrew |(see earlier in this supplement)} until freed by the {@spell greater restoration} spell or other magic. Any items the creature was wearing or carrying fall to the ground in its space, and if the creature dies while transformed, it remains in that form and doesn't revert.

trait.name: Wounded Fury
entries: While it has 25 hit points or fewer, the goosilisk has advantage on attack rolls. In addition, it deals an extra 3 ({@damage 1d6}) damage to any target it hits with a melee attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The goosilisk makes two beak attacks.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The octogoose can breath both air and water.

trait.name: Cavern Camouflage
entries: The octogoose has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made while underwater or in caves.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: The octogoose can move up to half its movement towards a creature it can see as a bonus action on its turn.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Webbed Feet
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this {@action grapple} ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and if the octogoose uses its webbed feet to attack another target, the {@condition grappled} target takes additional bludgeoning damage equal to half the damage dealt. The octogoose can only {@action grapple} one creature at a time.

action.name: Honk of Feathers (1/Day)
entries: The octogoose emits a magical honk and exudes a cloud of black feathers in a 20-foot radius sphere centered on itself. The area is {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|heavily obscured} for 1 minute, but can be dispersed by a strong wind if above ground, or a significant current if underwater. A creature that begins its turn in the area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or spend its action choking on the mass of feathers. A creature that is holding its breath or has its mouth covered automatically succeeds on this saving throw.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The poltergoose can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Invisigoose (2/Day)
entries: The poltergoose can use its action to turn {@condition invisible}. It remains {@condition invisible} for 1 hour, or until it ends it as a bonus action, makes a Beak attack, or takes radiant damage.

trait.name: Turn Immunity
entries: The poltergoose is immune to effects that would Turn undead.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Telekinetic Honk
entries: The poltergoose honks at a creature or unattended object within 30 feet of it. A creature must be Medium or smaller to be affected. Objects targeted can weigh up to 150 pounds. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be hurled up to 30 feet in a direction of the poltergoose's choosing, including upwards. If the creature comes into coming with a hard surface or heavy object, the target creature takes {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet moved. If the target is an object that isn't being worn or carried, the poltergoose hurls it up to 30 feet in any direction. If this would come into contact with a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet the object moved and be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The goose can hold its breath for 10 minutes while underwater.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Honk (1/Day)
entries: The goose honks aggressively at one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target creature must succeed on a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of the goose until the end of their next turn.

monsterFluff.name: Begander
entries: A begander is a beholder-kin formed from the dreams of a {@creature beholder} or {@creature death tyrant}, usually after being attacked or harassed by a flock of geese as it scouts for a new location for its lair. Once born, a begander quickly leaves to find its own isolation, its inherent xenophobia just as potent as that of its creator. From here the begander schemes and plots the downfall of mortalkind—and the rise of the goose!

entries.name: Multiple Heads
entries: Unlike other beholders, instead of eye stalks, the begander has eight heads, attached to its feathered form by long necks. The heads each have a distinct magical honk, similar to a conventional beholder's eye rays. Whenever one head is asleep, another is awake. Even as the begander dreams, it has at least two heads awake at a time, though they're usually too busy honking at each other to pay much attention to their surroundings.

entries.name: There Can Be Only One
entries: Like all beholders, the begander views itself as the first and last of its kind. If two beganders encounter one another, it almost always erupts in conflict.

monsterFluff.name: Gandra
entries: The pinnacle of goosely evolution, the gandra is a horrific product of magical manipulation and raw avian fury, capable of annihilating entire settlements overnight in its bid for world domination.

entries.name: Many Beaks
entries: The gandra has multiple heads, each of which houses a fearsome beak filled with jagged, sharp teeth, and is ever on the hunt for a new victim. Fortunately for their targets, a gandra's many heads are rarely co-operative, opting to engage in extensive honking matches and fight amongst themselves for dominance of its vast bulk instead of working together against a common foe.

entries.name: Bane of Hydras
entries: The gandra can often be found hunting other creatures that appear similar to it, most notably the {@creature hydra}. Though its lesser in strength, the gandra compensates for its shortcomings with unwavering fowlish determination, which makes it a large enough threat to give even the mightiest of {@creature hydra} a run for its money.

monsterFluff.name: Golden Dragoose
entries: The golden dragoose is a coastal dwelling dragon that feeds primarily on small fish. Their fur is said to retain some of the dragon's magical properties when woven into fabric, leading many to attempt to hunt the beast for its hide, much to their own detriment.

entries.name: Lakeside Loungers
entries: Golden dragoose love nothing more than to lounge around lakes, soaking up the sun on a warm summer's day. On particularly hot days, golden dragoose can be seen floating on the cool waters with their wings outstretched, their golden fur shimmering in the bright sunlight.

entries.name: Collectors of Feathered Friends
entries: When building its hoard, a golden dragoose opts for living treasures, rather than mundane or magical items, though it sometimes also takes simplistic items out of curiosity, such as brass bells or wooden doorknobs. These living treasures take the form of various water fowl or forest dwelling creatures, which the golden dragoose carefully plucks from regions it flys by, sometimes over 50 to 100 miles away. The creatures in the dragoose's menagerie rarely wander far from the dragoose's lakeside home, though if they do, the dragoose is usually far too lazy to bother searching for them.

entries.name: Enemy of Evildoers
entries: While aloof and lazy, it isn't uncommon to see collections of golden dragoose flock to sites of great evil, such as the battleground of a lich's undead army or murderous pirate ships out at sea, should word of the evil there reach their ears. Upon arriving, the dragoose beset their enemies with deafening honks and gouts of flame, incinerating weaker beings while carrying away any innocents caught in the crossfire to safety—sometimes even deciding they're valuable enough to join its mystical menagerie, regardless of whether the creature wants to or not.

monsterFluff.name: Gooseflayer
entries: The result of excessive {@creature mind flayer} experiments, the gooseflayer is a fearsome psionic foe that acts as a waterborne scout for colonies.

entries.name: Potent Psionics
entries: Through various experiments deep in the heart of an illithid colony, the gooseflayer's honk has been amplified with psionic might, granting it the ability to manifest spells to better aid its masters.

entries.name: Mischievous and Maniacal
entries: The gooseflayer is an inherently evil creature, using its psionics to disrupt trading vessels, or uproot trees to crush unfortunate passerby. Many adventurers have mistaken the gooseflayer to be simply a strange experiment-gone-wrong, approaching the creature with curiosity instead of caution. Before the unfortunate adventurers have time to react, the gooseflayer quickly lunges forward and unleashes a devastating honk, capable of shattering the mind and sending even the toughest of beasts reeling backwards in shock.

entries.name: Stubborn Minds
entries: While gooseflayers are created from the machinations of mindflayers, they're dogged stubbornness makes them difficult pets to control for long periods of time. Most mindflayers end up exhausted from the constant telepathic honks when ordering gaggles of gooseflayers to do its bidding, and only create as many gooseflayers as the colony needs. It is a powerful mindflayer indeed, that is capable of steering a flock of gooseflayers towards its target effectively. When an adventurer discovers more than a few gooseflayers in a region at once, it's a telltale sign multiple mindflayers—or perhaps even a colony—is at work close by.

monsterFluff.name: Goosilisk
entries: A magical offshoot of the menacing {@creature basilisk}, this murderous creature transforms its foes into harmless {@creature pond goose|CircleoftheHonk|pond geese}, keeping them in stony cages for its next meal.

entries.name: Waterborne Hunters
entries: Goosilisks thrive in aquatic locations, and can be found scattered around environments regardless of temperature. Goosilisks are most often found lurking in marshlands or lakes.

entries.name: Become Goose
entries: The goosilisk shares a similar supernatural feature to that of its {@creature basilisk} kin, but doesn't have the ability to turn its prey to stone with a gaze. Instead, a creature unfortunate enough to catch the goosilisk's beady eyes might find themselves subject to a low, gutteral honk, which transforms them into a harmless {@creature pond goose|CircleoftheHonk}. The creature rarely gets time to adapt or understand its new form before the goosilisk lunges at them with a fearsome savagery, the new creature now a perfect, feathery meal.

entries.name: Valuable Blood
entries: A goosilisk's blood is highly prized in alchemical concoctions, and is said to retain some of the goosilisk's polymophic properties. In times of war, goosilisk blood is manufactured into fragile bottles and thrown into enemy lines using slings. Upon impact, the potion shatters, emitting a sudden burst of gaseous liquid that, if inhaled, mimics the creature's goosifying properties for a short time. While these effects are only temporary, a goose-vial assault can quickly turn the tide of a close battle, sowing confusion and panic amidst soldiers as their regiments transform into squawking, flustered water fowl.

monsterFluff.name: Octogoose
entries: A bloodthirsty beast, born of twisted magic that lurks in coastal caverns, attacking anyone unfortunate enough to come across it.

entries.name: Aggressive Omnivores
entries: Octogeese are quick and nimble ambush predators that use their multiple legs to quickly catch up to and overwhelm their prey. Octogeese are omnivorous, but prefer the taste of fish. Pods of octogeese have been known to surround small fishing vessels and batter them into submission before stealing any fish they may have collected for themselves.

entries.name: Malicious Hunters
entries: Octogeese enjoy toying with their prey before going in for the final kill, using their webbed feet to bat their target around before plunging them head first into nearby water sources, attempting to drown them.

monsterFluff.name: Poltergoose
entries: A troublesome avian spirit often found terrorizing small fishing villages, the poltergoose is a frustrating foe to face for an unprepared adventurer.

entries.name: Malice and Menace
entries: The poltergoose is a creature of pure hatred and menace. When first encountered, the poltergoose assails its victims with fish which it telekinetically plucks from nearby waters. Should its target stand its ground, the poltergoose quickly changes tactics, picking up its foes and slamming them repeatedly into nearby objects, or holding them underwater in an attempt to drown them.

entries.name: Bound Spirits
entries: Like other ghosts, the poltergoose often haunts a location or individual responsible for its untimely death, though wandering poltergoose also attach themselves to unknowing individuals in order to travel great distances, or sow unprovoked chaos.

entries.name: Rage Unending
entries: While conventional ghosts can be controlled by wizards or sorcerers, poltergeese can't be magically subdued into obedience. However, a poltergoose will enter freely into a limited-time servitude, should a creature prove themselves to be an ally of the poltergoose's destructive behaviour, or provide the poltergoose with a particularly unique treasure

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A poltergoose doesn't require air, food, drink or sleep.
For The Druid That Decided Peace Was Never An Option

entries.name: Introduction
entries: Backed into a corner in a dusty tavern, a bloodied bandit stares in horror at the towering beast above him. He raises his sword to strike, but is met with a flurry of feathers and a serrated beak.

An elderly woman tends to her garden before shrieking in panic as her watering can crashes to the floor. Turning around, she catches a glimpse of a white tail and yellow feet vanishing around the corner, her gardening shears nowhere to be seen.

A rugged adventurer winces as a heavy axe splinters their shield and knocks them to the floor. A vicious troll bears down on the would-be hero, preparing for the final strike. The adventurer grins, ancient druidic magic tingling at their fingertips before lunging towards the troll, their form now that of a monstrous, white-feathered water fowl.

entries.name: Circle of the Honk Spells
entries: The spells listed below are listed by spell level. While these spells are intended for use only with the {@class Druid|PHB||Circle of the Honk|CircleoftheHonk} subclass, they can also be available to conventional druids or other classes noted in the spell properties, at the DM's discretion.

entries.name: Goose Forms
entries: Below are a collection of new goose forms for your druid circle, in order of challenge rating. Some also feature lore, should you wish to add them into your campaign as wandering monsters (or bosses!)
